thread.title: 'BTTF' shoes, Trump; 'MythBusters' ending; 'Cruel Intentions' TV show: PM Buzz
thread.title_full: 'BTTF' shoes, Trump; 'MythBusters' ending; 'Cruel Intentions' TV show: PM Buzz | syracuse.com

author: Geoff Herbert | gherbert@syracuse.com
title: 'BTTF' shoes, Trump; 'MythBusters' ending; 'Cruel Intentions' TV show: PM Buzz
text:
Marty McFly's self-lacing Nike Air Mags from " Back to the Future Part II " are now real -- and only Michael J. Fox has a pair. The actor received the company's first pair of sneakers with actual power laces on "Back to the Future" Day Wednesday, and the rest of us can get one in spring 2016. "Although the project started as science fiction, we're now proud to turn that fiction into fact," designer Tinker Hatfield says. It's unclear how many pairs will be made or how much they'll cost -- Nike sold replicas without self-lacing technology in 2011 for $8,750 -- but proceeds will go to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Disease research.
» Read more at The Verge .
Speaking of "BTTF," writer Bob Gale has now confirmed, once and for all, that Biff Tannen is based on Donald Trump . In "Part II," Thomas F. Wilson's character becomes "America's greatest living folk hero" and a powerful casino owner (whose building resembles Trump Tower) in an alternate timeline for 1985. "We thought about it when we made the movie! Are you kidding?" Gale says of the similarities between Biff and the 2016 presidential candidate.
» Read more at The Daily Beast .
The Discovery Channel's "MythBusters" is ending after 14 season s, the network announced. Adam Savage and Jamie Hyneman's famous experiments will still "continue to live on" at the Science Channel in syndication, but the last of nearly 250 episodes will air early next year. "Making MythBusters has fundamentally and irrevocably altered the way I think as a person, as an artist, and as a scientist. I'm glad for the chance to say goodbye with some of the best television we've ever made. I will miss making this show," Savage said. The final season premieres Sunday, Jan. 3 at 8 p.m. on Discovery.
» Read more at E! News .
NBC has bought a script for a "Cruel Intentions" TV show based on the 1999 movie that starred Reese Witherspoon, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Ryan Phillippe and Selma Blair. The modern-day reboot will follow Bash Casey, the 16-year-old son of Sebastian and Annette, who finds his late father's journal and brings what he learned about sex and power to Brighton Preparatory Academy in San Francisco. No cast has been announced.
» Read more at Variety .
And Jennifer Lawrence reunites with David O. Russell in the first trailer for "Joy." The actress appears to be gunning (literally) for an Oscar again with the "Silver Linings Playbook" and American Hustle" director, playing a married mother who starts her own business against all odds and finds success. Based on the true story of "Miracle Mop" inventor Joy Mangano, "Joy" -- also starring Bradley Cooper -- opens just in time for awards season on December 25.
